& 
grade

Height allowances
enable a variety of
architectural styles
while preserving the
residential scale of our
neighborhoods as well
as the privacy and
natural light available
to each lot.

Height limit = 33'

Fig 43 Determining slope of roof

12"
run

6"
rise

Roof slope is the vertical rise in
inches for every horizontal distance
of twelve inches (called the "run"). It
is expressed as rise:run or, in this
example 6:12.

Note: On a drawing this slope
might also be represented as:

12
6

or

2
1

Height measured to top of roof material

30'

12 : 12

12 : 10

12 : 6

12 : 3

Height limit = 30'

visual_elements.description: A table titled 'Structure' and 'Max. height to roof peak' listing different dwelling types and their maximum allowed roof peak heights. It includes rows for 'Main dwelling on a standard lot with a roof slope <12:12', 'Main dwelling on a standard lot with a roof slope ≥12:12', 'Main dwelling on a substandard or flag lot', 'Accessory structure in rear or side yard', and '2nd-dwelling units'.

A diagram illustrating how to determine the slope of a roof. It shows a cross-section of a roof with a horizontal measurement labeled '12" run' and a vertical measurement labeled '6" rise'. The diagram also includes a gutter at the bottom right of the roof section.
A diagram showing two alternative ways to represent roof slope: '12 over 6' and '2 over 1', depicted as right triangles with the respective side lengths.
visual_elements.location: Middle-right of the page, below the roof slope explanation

visual_elements.description: A series of five house silhouettes with different roof slopes, all aligned to a common base and two different height limits. The houses are labeled with their roof slopes (12:14, 12:12, 12:10, 12:6, 12:3). The first two houses (12:14 and 12:12) are shown under a 'Height limit = 33'' line, and the last three houses (12:10, 12:6, 12:3) are shown under a 'Height limit = 30'' line. A horizontal line above the houses is labeled 'Height measured to top of roof material'.

technical_specifications.parameter: Max. height to roof peak for Main dwelling on a standard lot with a roof slope <12:12
Max. height to roof peak for Main dwelling on a standard lot with a roof slope ≥12:12

Max. height to roof peak for Accessory structure in rear or side yard

Height limit for roof slopes 12:14 and 12:12
Height limit for roof slopes 12:10, 12:6, and 12:3

sections: Height allowances enable a variety of architectural styles while preserving the residential scale of our neighborhoods as well as the privacy and natural light available to each lot.
Roof slope is the vertical rise in inches for every horizontal distance of twelve inches (called the "run"). It is expressed as rise:run or, in this example 6:12.
Note: On a drawing this slope might also be represented as:
Height measured to top of roof material
